comments.commentBody: The dire wolves and The Unsullied have certainly left a lot to be desired in terms of their reputations for being unstoppable opponents. They kind of remind me of the Crack Suicide Squad from the Judean People's Front in Monty Python's 'Life of Brian'.
I think the wolves will return. They are the glue.

That was utterly brilliant writing right there, and the ending of that episode is going to stay with me for a while. I feel punched in the heart, unable to articulate what I'm thinking.

However, my theory that all the direwolves have to die for the Starks to be reunited and take control again is slowly, sadly becoming true. All the signs point to it. Nymeria and Ghost are the only ones left (if Shaggydog really is dead).

Martin, when you're cutting all that rosemary, I hope you're playing this. One of my favorites but I didn't hear it tonight on the Billboard music awards.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Og7JS8mcp3c
Could we please dispense with the political commentary?  This is the third week in a row and last week my response wasn't even published, so it is not even fair or balanced.
It reminds me much more of Clinton.
You cannot say "please dispense with the political commentary" in one post and then write political commentary in the next one. That does NOT work in a truly democratic society.

Does anyone else see a strange and chilling parallel between Euron and Trump?  Both have done all kinds of stuff other than lead, but now insist with a maniacal gleam in their eyes that they are the only true leader... yikes. And Euron's focus on the physical - eerie same thing with Trump. The GoT writers are on to something there - how will that end?  Sad to say bye to Max von Sydow's character and Bran's direwolf - they did not have much screentime, but made up for that with force of character. The strange running away of Yara and Theon Greyjoy mirrors the scattering of the Stark children - can't any family stay together on this show? But this episode will be remembered for Hodor's story - so tragic. We will miss him - as we miss the brave and the true. As we will miss Jorah, unless he does that that elusive cure. They are both too good for this wicked, twisted world. How we wish Melisandre had some magic for both of them. Now, how will Bran escape the White Walkers at his heels? Has the Raven taught him enough, and does he have enough powers to survive? There is nothing between him and a terrible end but snow - and whatever power he possesses.
Funny you should say that.  Last night's episode was directed by Jack Bender, who directed 38 episode of 'Lost' - another show where the writers didn't know the ending when the filming started.
I think you may have missed an episode, or a scene in an episode.

That's the time travel paradox. It's true, Hordor was already Hordor before Bran got his powers (perhaps even before Bran was born).

So Hordor's transformation took place in the past when the future Bran, with his new powers, went to the past.

That doesn't mean anything goes. In the GoT world, it seems that if you go back into the past and interfere in any way, it is sort of 'meant to be', i.e. that altered past is what make the present (Hordor being with them, saving them) possible.

Last night I was trying to figure out if the Three-Eyed Raven leading Bran to Winterfell in the past as the White Walkers are barging in meant he can see the future. My conclusion was he doesn't have to:

He has seen everything in the past - how Hordor being Hordor helped Bran fled Winterfell and everything after that lead to this day. He of course also saw himself and Bran making Hordor who he is in the past. So he doesn't really have to know the future by seeing it directly - by seeing what they did on their time travel to the past, he could infer the future - when and how he would die in the future, and that his successor would be Bran, and what he had to do to save Bran...

Last week when Danny walked out of the burning building, it reminded me of the liquid metal Terminator walking through fire in T2. This week the scene between Danny and Ser Jorah reminded me the ending of that movie, where the young John Connor desperately tried to prevent the death of T-800: “No! It'll be okay! I command you not to die! I order you not to die...”

The music during that scene was just perfect. And good for Ser Jorah, finally learned his lesson and came clean about a secret that could cost him his place with Danny. He deserved to be cured like Shireen.

I naively thought that’d be the most bitter-sweet/tragic scene of the episode. Then we lost Summer. Then Hordor.

Let me get this straight: the Three-Eyed Raven takes Bran into the past, just so that poor child can be caught in this mind-controll mobius time loop, becoming Hordor, so one day in the future he can be used to help Bran?!
This is one of the most emotionally devastating thing ever on this show. This somehow felt way worse than Ned's death. Poor Wyllis, yet another collateral damage in the game of thrones. There are no small parts Hordor. We will miss you greatly.
Bran clearly doesn't know what his power is all about. His control of said powers is a requirement or the Night King's army is going to win.

What a poignant image of Hodor single-handedly holding back the army of White Walkers. He will be missed, but glad he was given such a heroic final scene.  Bran's just wreaking all kinds of havoc with this time traveling.  He's clearly not ready to handle his newfound power. Now the Night's King has the opening he's been waiting for. I was wondering what he and his horsemen had been up to since Hardhome.  It's easy to forget sometimes that this is a fantasy story, but this week's episode really brought the fantasy part back in a big way.

Bran HAD to go and pull a Pippin. What isn't explicitly revealed is to what extent Bran was aware of and endeavoring to hold the door at the expense of Hodor's life. I'm appreciating the temporal connections made in this latest chapter of the GOT saga.

If Arya could somehow run and hide from the Faceless Men it would be a huge blow to the credibility of the show in my opinion. She's either going to have to become a faceless, nameless assassin or be granted some sort of dispensation by the Many Faced God.

I join all of your questions about Arya....if she leaves the Faceless Men can she take her 'gift' with her?

Also am getting distracted (on purpose) by her anagram character, Yara.
Theon's hangdog face needs fixing and am thinking a Stark (re)alliance might cheer him up a bit. So much potential for the Ironborn navy when potential allies (and their armies) are separated by a ocean.

So much happening as many female characters come into their own.
Very surprised you were one of the only folks on any medium to make note of Bran being "marked" by a White Walker and what that might mean for the future.

Arya has questions about why the Faceless Man is ordering a hit on an actress that seems harmless. Makes me wonder if she's going to veer off this path before she becomes one of them.

Are the White Walkers and wights now south of the Wall?
Thanks, Mr. Parsons - and Dr. K - you covered most of the relevant points with regard to Mr. Sanders. I couldn't have said it better.
Vast stretches of Brooklyn also have no train service.  Those who live in the sprawling area between the B and Q trains' routes and that of the L line know what I'm referring to.

NYC more or less abandoned building subway lines in the 1940's.  There have been marginal fixes but vast areas of Brooklyn and Queens never received the subway service they deserved and the powers that be were content to have them have to take a bus to the train.  Contrast that to Paris where every address in the city is within 100 meters of a metro station and a new line is being built.  And let's not leave out Manhattan where there is one line east of 6th Avenue that is totally inadequate for the crowds getting to work.  A sad sa commentary on our city.

Actually, Jeff, there's a whole component of the transportation system that disappeared starting in the 40s, which explains the glaring gaps in outer-borough service. There used to be an extensive network of streetcars service Queens and Brooklyn. Those lines were bought out by Standard Oil, GM, and Firestone, which shut them down one by one. They wanted people to drive or take buses, both of which increased demand for their products. During the same time frame, additional elevated subway lines were also decommissioned. This is why we're hurting now.

Surface congestion is too bad to permit resurrection of streetcars, but elevated additions to the subway line would be a relatively easy and cheap way of increasing the network quickly. New train stock runs much more quietly than even the newest trains we have on the rails now. NIMBYs are going to have to be denied--we need more trains or the system will break.

The city needs more subways and more express lines.  At least Brooklyn has service; vast stretches of outer Queens have bus service only.  The system has not been extended much since before World War II.
How about making jobs available?  And raising the minimum wage, so those jobs aren't pitiful.
It's jobs, jobs, jobs, and at decent wages.  Th absence of jobs in poor communities is utterly destructive.
Vast stretches of Brooklyn also have no train service.  Those who live in the sprawling area between the B and Q trains' routes and that of the L line know what I'm referring to.
History shows that black men with guns are a strong impulse to enacting gun controls.

The original 1968 - 1975 express had that service pattern. Expresses started at Coney Island (or Avenue X) and ran express from Kings Hwy to Jay Street. Locals started at Kings Hwy and ran local from Kings Hwy to Jay Street. I lived in Kensington until 1990 and the lack of a 'F' express was always an issue. For that service pattern to return the MTA has to install a switch near Kings Hwy that was removed years ago. With all the large apartment complexes being constructed at the southern end of the 'F' the MTA needs to consider adding more trains in the next few years.

Lots of trains on the F line are already running express in Brooklyn as a consequence of so-called "service delays" in the evening.  They might as well make it official- and to skip the four stops between Kings Highway and 18th Avenue for the express route while they're at it.  Those of us who live even further towards Coney Island will be most appreciative.

JFC, one of your recent Avatars used this version in a film.

https://youtu.be/QLAqx8JxLFA

Martin, one time a little convenience store near where I worked was closing (possibly moving to a new location?). Everything was marked down by half. So a bunch of us trooped over during lunch. I don't know what anyone else bought. I bought little jars of herbs and spices. I was stunned that they still had more than one jar of whatever I might need; at half-price, it was almost not highway robbery.

Rosemary does quite well indoors in a big pot, and eliminates the need for air freshener, but the sun exposure can't always be arranged in every house.

.
Maybe so, Martin, but I'm leaning toward the Commenter who uses the tilde properly.

.
Don't feel bad Jim. These things are random sometimes.

Someone's comment used the phrase "I had to look up Uranus"; I don't know if it was delayed, but it did appear here.
To William Rhoden ~ As usual you've written an insightful essay.  I enjoyed reading it.  Thank you.
Martin, who was the biggest loser in the Civil War? I will give you a hint. It wasn't the South,

Nice wordplay with all those body parts. Congratulations Ori.

It was also quite scrabbly; I was looking for a Q and Z towards the end, the only letters not in the puzzle as it turned out. I appreciated the lack of silly abbreviations.

It's clothesline weather here, so I don't have to use my DRYER.

I had a serious heart attack at age 61 back at the beginning of April.  My parents are both 90; all 4 grandparents lived into their late 80's & early 90's. I figured I had the genes that would keep me safe. This was despite the fact that over the last 25 years, I had gained 60 lbs, didn't exercise enough, had borderline high blood pressure, was at the upper limit of "safe" cholesterol levels. In other words, I had multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease.  My GP would tell me each year at my annual physical to lose weight & get more exercise.  And I didn't do anything about it.  I kidded myself into thinking I was eating healthy.  I had plenty of salads, ate plenty of fish and poultry & didn't eat red meat, & ate plenty of fruit.  But I also used bottled salad dressing & pre-cooked turkey on those salads.  I ate canned fish, "diet" ice cream bars & boxed breakfast cereal;  just way too much processed food.  I also ate out a lot.  Well, when I got out of the hospital in April, I started scrutinizing what I had been eating, & really read the labels & did the math. I was shocked at the amounts of sugar & salt I was eating in the processed foods that made up half of my diet.  And finally, because I had almost died, & was looking at a dramatically shortened life as a result of my heart attack, I have started paying attention.   As others have said in their comments, the key is getting back to natural food & cooking it yourself.  I'm doing that now and feel so much better.

Ricky -- rather condescending to suggest that low income people don't have the moxie to figure out how to make a pasta dinner for themselves.  As for the cost, I do not know how low income people can afford all this prepared food.  Frozen dinners are not cheap at all especially compared with how much it would cost to make the same thing at home.  They're all starch based (super cheap, readily available), frozen vegetables, and some ground beef or bits of chicken.  All that stuff is readily available at any grocery store. How long does it take to fill a pot with water and turn on the stove?  chopped meats can actually be cooked in a microwave and so can the frozen vegetables.  Pasta with chicken and mixed vegetables can be cooked at home in 15 minutes.  In ten minutes you can have a baked potato stuffed with vegetables and smothered in grated cheese.  Tuna casserole can be assembled in no time, cooked on Sunday night and reheated for Tuesday dinner in three minutes. A big pot of rice and beans in the fridge can be adapted to many inexpensive tasty meals in minutes. Take turns cleaning up the cooking pots and let everyone wash their own bowl and glass.  Bingo. It takes a little organizing and forethought but it's pretty simple.  Agreed some neighborhoods don't have great shopping resources but any market carries basic ingredients like rice, beans, frozen vegetables, cans of tuna and so forth. "td" was a bit harsh and frustrated but speaks truth.

That is pretty circuitous thinking, and makes some crazy assumptions. I'd say "some white people have given up in disgust at the violence in black communities" but they are NOT doing so out of racism (many are liberals) and all of them are horrified at the violence depicted in this article. Nobody wants to live in an city where large areas are "no go zones" for white people (as is the case in my hometown, or Detroit, or many other large older cities).

If you have a brilliant plan for making "guns less available" to JUST poor black men -- without violating the Constitution -- please let us know what it is. Cities like NYC and Chicago and the whole state of California have draconian gun laws for just this reason. How's that working out?

The availability of guns fosters gun violence in black communities and gives whites a reason or excuse to be racist, or at least to vote for people who will keep this violence away and make sure guns are easily available.  Violent black neighborhoods give whites a reason to vote for conservatives who follow policies that do nothing to cure the violence, because the violence gets them votes.

Well summed up. PK cherry picks, magnifies the least important and ignores the most important. He calculates and manipulates, like his favorite candidate, and pretends the differences betw the parties are bigger than they are. He also ignores Piketty, who says Reaganism influenced both parties---Hillary is continuity and Sanders a discontinuity.
